awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Fire Impacts, Remediation, and Education (FIRE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

A warmer and drier climate has supplied abundant fuel (e.g., dry brush) for wildfires, drastically increasing fire activity across much of western North America in the past decades. Wildfires burn through forests, shrublands, and grasslands, leaving marked societal and environmental scars. Wildfire impacts are not limited to the burned area or the short term, instead extending beyond the burn region and over the long term, e.g., health-related issues due to wildfire smoke reaching across state and national borders. The targeted societal and environmental impacts of this project range from the safety, well-being, and physical and psychological health of society to the safety and well-being of ecosystems at all scales, from microbial to global. The impacts can be direct and immediate, such as fatalities and injuries, or indirect and long-term, such as the financial burden on public and private entities and the health effect of pollution due to widespread smoke and contamination of groundwater by acidic rain or fire retardants. The proposed vision is to plan and establish an engineering research center (ERC), FIRE (fire, impacts, remediation, education), by a diverse team that will use a convergent approach and strategy to reach objectives of: (i) identifying the complex relation between wildfires and their broad, direct and indirect, short- and long-term impacts on the society and environment; (ii) identifying expertise necessary to study these impacts; (iii) identifying various stakeholders impacted by or impacting wildfires; (iv) establishing a continuous communication channel with these stakeholders; and (v) creating a strategic plan for the formation of a team of experts and stakeholders to ultimately find innovative and cost-effective ways to mitigate the problem, remediate and restore the environment after wildfires, and educate the public to help the mitigation and ensure their safety during and after wildfires. 

The grant activities include a kick-off meeting at Boise State, literature review, regular meetings and interviews with identified stakeholders to learn about impacts and other stakeholders, a major five-part workshop, reaching out to and attracting experts to fill gaps in the team's expertise, visiting up to a total of 12 ERCs to learn from successful ERC leaders, a series of physical and weekly cyber team-meetings, preparing initial drafts of an ERC proposal, two rounds of review, and revision of the ERC proposal.  As mentioned, a major activity of the project is a five-part workshop held at Boise State where ERC leaders, national and local experts and community leaders, representatives from state and federal agencies, members of the insurance industry, and leading scientists and entrepreneurs will train the team and a larger group of researchers on developing successful proposals for and running sustainable ERCs; communication with and engaging stakeholders and educating the public; enhancing a culture of inclusion and diversity; and the science and various other aspects of wildfires, their impacts, and impact mitigation. The project will also leverage the PIs' past collaboration with diversity institutions and inclusion of an associate director for diversity into the team to enhance the culture of inclusion, diversity, and sustainability within the ERC team throughout the planning grant, subsequent ERC, academic/professional communities, and society. We will work toward improved involvement of and communication with the public and private stakeholders (i.e., parties impacted by or impacting wildfires, including national and state agencies such as the Forest Services and Bureau of Land Management, policymakers, and leaders of communities and industries at high risk of wildfire) and prepare a well-thought proposal for a sustainable ERC that will ultimately help mitigate wildfires' negative impacts. The strategy to make this possible is understanding the complex fire-weather relations and impacts, developing data-driven predictive fire characteristic models, and educating the public to help prevent human-ignited wildfires and ensure public safety during wildfires and avoid harm from short- and long-term impacts. There will also be a focus on team and capacity building necessary to reach the above-mentioned goals via the proposed strategies. To better implement these steps via planning and developing the proposed ERC, the team will learn from prior ERCs across the United States and leverage their experience to design a sustainable ERC better adapted to new ERC requirements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wildfires are an integral component of forested lands and provide benefits to the ecosystem. While a century of fire exclusion has contributed to wildfire increase, the warming climate has also led to longer hotter seasons, and drought, leading to an abundance of fuel for wildfires. The fire size, duration, and frequency have escalated in the Western U.S. Recent studies also discovered changes in fire behavior such as fire progression into higher elevations in the Western United States. This expansion into more seasons and regions has reached the wildland-urban interface (referred to as WUI), resulting in amplified loss of life and property—either by the fire itself or by cascading post-fire impacts.

Wildfire impacts are not just short-term or limited to burned regions, instead extending beyond the burn region and time and into long-term, cascading, and indirect impacts that are not well understood. For example, a long-term impact is health-related issues due to smoke from wildfires, compromising cardiovascular and respiratory systems, even in healthy individuals. The consequences are more fatal in youth, the elderly, and individuals with respiratory issues. This impact is not completely understood.

Another indirect impact is the loss of vegetation, leading to mudslides during flash floods. A recent example was the Montecito mudslide after the Thomas Fire in California. Despite the well-implemented evacuation and protection of residences (the wildfire took the life of one firefighter), after residents returned to their homes, the mudslide led to the loss of 21 lives. This impact is not well understood either.

Fire suppressants that use Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS) and perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) used to extinguish or retard fire have appeared in drinking water near sites where firefighters extinguished fires. An example is at the Dyess Air Force Base in Texas, where a fire suppressant foam was linked to the shutdown of two drinking water wells, and the Defense Department launched an investigation to determine how widespread similar problems were across the nation.

Traditionally, the attention of federal emergency agencies and public media has focused on earthquakes and hurricanes, not wildfires, even though wildfire impacts can be more devastating and longer lasting. For example, in September 2017, while Hurricane Harvey wreaked havoc on the Gulf of Texas, taking the lives of 82 people, the Western United States was blanketed under a plume of smoke that extended from coast to coast, covering Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Wyoming, Montana, the Dakotas, and Nebraska. Only in one of those wildfires (Thomson wildfire in California), 21 lives were lost due to the post-fire mudslide. In the past decades, federal fire suppression costs have slowly escalated to billions of dollars. These are the motivations behind this project.

The vision of this project was to form a large team to comprehensively study the complex relationship between wildfires and their broad, cascading impacts on the local-to-global society and environment.

To find the most successful path to understanding and mitigating all wildfire impacts, one needs to first communicate with parties impacted by or fighting wildfires. Thus, we first identified wildfire stakeholders, including distinguished leaders of agencies, the community, industry, academia, insurance firms, and policymakers.

Through the support of this project, the core team (three PIs) of the project identified an exhaustive list of direct, indirect, short-term, and long-term impacts of wildfires and gaps in the existing knowledge. We then formed a large team of experts in engineering, physical to social sciences, and public policy across five universities, with the necessary expertise to study wildfire impacts.

Throughout the project, we learned about new impacts, not originally thought connected to wildfires and ways tried by stakeholders to restore the environment. For example, we researched the impacts of wildfires on soils (e.g., burned soils lose their nutrients, are rendered hydrophobic, and become more alkaline, causing the loss of vegetation for an extended period, thus leading to erosion and mudslides). We also identified practices implemented by stakeholders, like forest services, and their shortcomings. We further investigated innovative, sustainable ways to restore burned soil and learned about the social and educational aspects of wildfire management as well as human response to and perception of wildfire smoke.

We extensively researched another indirect hazard, i.e., the contamination of soil and surface/groundwater due to PFAS post-fire.

 

In addition, we created a communication channel with various ERC leaders across the U.S., who target other grand challenges, to learn about the mechanics and logistics of working in and sustaining a large research team and pitfalls along the way.

Another outcome was the mentoring of younger scientists and four graduate students to help them gain the expertise necessary to join the workforce serving the wildfire stakeholders.

Furthermore, we developed a preproposal that was submitted to NSF. After receiving feedback from reviewers, we continued to improve the said preproposal.

Moreover, we disseminated our learning through means such as conferences, journals, and meetings.

Modified by: Arvin Farid
